children.content:
Data literacy is the ability to read, understand, create, and
communicate data as information. It involves skills to interpret data
accurately, critically evaluate its sources, and use it effectively to
make informed decisions. In today’s data-driven world, data literacy
empowers individuals and organisations to navigate vast amounts of
information, discern patterns, and apply insights across various
contexts, including healthcare, business, and public policy. Developing
data literacy is essential not only for specialists but also for the
general public to participate meaningfully in discussions and decisions
influenced by data.

The interest of this research in data literacy centres on the role of
data in enhancing awareness and understanding of the body and illness.
By improving individuals’ perception of their bodies and the data
related to them, data literacy aims to empower people to engage more
actively in managing their health, make informed decisions and develop a
deeper connection between their subjective experiences and objective
information.

children.name: From technical competences to awareness
children.content:
Data literacy has taken many forms over time, shaped by historical
contexts, disciplinary viewpoints, and societal expectations. Early
definitions, grounded in professional environments, focused on technical
skills such as accessing, manipulating, and analysing data with tools
like statistical software and visualisation programs (Schield, 2004;
Wolff, 2016). These views reflect a period in which data work was
primarily the responsibility of experts. As digital technologies became
widespread and began generating large volumes of personal and societal
data, the concept broadened to include non experts. Citizens are
increasingly expected to understand how data is collected, stored, and
used, and to engage with questions of privacy, consent, and bias (Yates,
2021). This shift underscores that data is never neutral but emerges
from decisions, values, and power structures (Kitchin, 2014; Drucker,
2011).

This evolution shows that data literacy connects to multiple
disciplines. Related fields such as information literacy, numeracy,
media literacy, and statistical literacy each contribute perspectives on
how people access, interpret, and critically evaluate information. More
recent approaches expand this view by emphasising critical thinking,
ethical awareness, and cultural context, recognising that data practices
are situated within sociotechnical systems. Concepts such as Human Data
Interaction (Mortier et al., 2014) and data empowerment (D’Ignazio,
2017; Data pop Alliance, 2015) shift attention from technical skill
alone to enabling agency, supporting individuals to question data
practices, participate in decision making, and exercise control over
their digital lives.

Inverarity et al. (2022) at the Open Data Institute identify a dual
trajectory in data literacy development. Industry and public sectors
prioritise technical competence, focusing on data management,
processing, and tool use to meet organisational needs, often through
standardised training with limited contextual depth (Yousef et al.,
2021). In contrast, academia advances a holistic approach that combines
technical skills with critical thinking, ethical awareness, and
contextual understanding. This academic perspective seeks to empower
individuals to question how data is produced and applied, supporting
reflective and responsible engagement with data.

children.name: Making sense of persona data
children.content:
In healthcare, these developments are particularly significant. Data
literacy enables patients to move beyond passive data provision toward
active engagement with their health information. Literacy fosters
awareness of how data relates to their bodies, supports communication
with clinicians, and strengthens their capacity to challenge the
dominance of objective measures that may overlook lived experience. As
Fotopoulou (2020, 2021) notes, prioritizing empowerment over technical
instruction ensures that data literacy can address inequalities by
equipping individuals and communities to use data meaningfully in their
own contexts.

This research adopts a broadened view of data literacy as a
sociocultural process that connects embodied experience, critical
reflection, and collective action. While technical skills are
acknowledged as valuable, they are not the primary source of expertise
for this research. Instead, expertise is rooted in lived experience,
particularly in relation to illness, care, and medical practices. Data
literacy is therefore understood not as technical skills alone but as
the capacity to make sense of information through personal relevance,
transforming individual traces into shared knowledge that supports
agency and accountability.

children.name: Creative and participatory approaches to literacy
children.content:
This approach draws on Freire’s critical pedagogy, which understands
literacy as an emancipatory process grounded in engagement with one’s
own reality. Building on these principles, D’Ignazio and Bhargava (2018)
argue that working with data connected to people’s lived contexts
supports understanding, agency, and reflection. Their work shows that
non expert audiences often relate more easily to narrative and
contextual forms than to numerical abstraction, highlighting the need
for creative and accessible ways of engaging with data.

Several methods have been developed to cultivate this ability. Data
biographies invite participants to trace how datasets are produced,
including the decisions, contexts, and omissions that shape them,
fostering a critical awareness of data’s constructed nature (D’Ignazio,
2017). Data fragments and annotations encourage participants to reflect
on and critique their own data, using annotation as a means to question
and interpret information (Thompson, 2020). Attention to gaps and
anomalies, as seen in self-tracking practices, further supports this
process by showing that absences in data can be as meaningful as what is
present (Lupton, 2017; West et al., 2017).

Participatory approaches play a central role in developing these
capacities. Learning within communities allows individuals to share
experiences, question assumptions, and develop collective understanding
(McCosker et al., 2022). In such contexts, personal data becomes a
resource for shared reflection and action rather than a private and
isolated asset (Karyda et al., 2020). Collective engagement fosters
solidarity and relevance, making data practices more meaningful and
sustainable (Hummel & Braun, 2020).

For the reasons above, data literacy, in this research, is approached as
a participatory and transformative practice that links personal
experience with collective knowledge-making. This perspective moves away
from seeing data as a static resource to be consumed, which is instead
treated as something to interpreted, questioned, and shaped through
active engagement.

Within this perspective, data becomes a living element of dialogue,
connecting individual sensations and narratives to broader social and
clinical contexts. Personal data is not confined to private use but
serves as a medium for shared understanding, where meaning is negotiated
and developed collaboratively. This orientation positions data literacy
as essential to participatory healthcare, providing the critical
capacity to ensure that experiences are not only represented but also
influence how health knowledge is produced and applied. Through design,
this approach turns data literacy into a source of agency, fostering
accountability and supporting more inclusive, situated forms of care.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
In recent years, design research has increasingly integrated
participatory practices, recognising the value of interdisciplinary
collaboration. Participatory methodologies enable researchers to gain
deeper insights and produce more inclusive outcomes by involving diverse
stakeholders in co-creation processes. These approaches support active
engagement and create conditions in which participants exchange
viewpoints and shape new understandings together.

This research adopts a participatory approach to foster collaboration
between individuals with lived experience of illness and medical
experts. Participation is used to create dialogue between scientific
knowledge and everyday realities, supporting mutual learning and deeper
understanding. Such collaboration seeks to generate forms of knowledge
that cannot be produced by any individual alone. The research examines
how participation can be intentionally structured to include people with
diverse roles and expertise, enabling the co-creation of inclusive and
contextually grounded knowledge. The approach is based on the premise
that collaboration among those with shared concerns strengthens
understanding and practice. Within this framework, the study explores
how participatory processes rooted in design can build data literacy by
supporting people in collecting, interpreting, and communicating their
own data.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
Participation in healthcare emerges within a landscape where design and
medical practice meet and respond to complex and interdependent
challenges. Design helps reveal issues that remain unnoticed, supports
interpretation of experience, and facilitates communication among groups
that work with different forms of knowledge. Healthcare offers a setting
that requires careful attention to problems, practices, and
relationships, making it a fertile ground for design engagement. Within
this setting, participatory design enables the creation of knowledge
that arises from situated perspectives and brings attention to voices
that are often absent from standard healthcare procedures. Chauhan
(2021) describes how design integrates experience, intent, and expertise
to improve conditions and address emerging needs. This view understands
participation as a shared activity among clinicians, patients,
caregivers, and others whose lived experiences contribute to knowledge
that is distributed, contextual, and shaped through practice.

Mishra and Sandhu (2021) identify three ways in which design can support
healthcare processes: framing problems from a user-centred perspective,
creating space for learning and solution generation, and engaging
communities and organisations from the earliest stages of defining
issues. Consistent with this, the Stanford d.school design process
(Hasso Plattner Institute of Design, 2019) highlights the importance of
understanding those involved by including them in shaping problems and
questions. Co-design practices build on this principle by activating the
knowledge, skills, and resources of individuals and groups to create
solutions that reflect shared concerns (Alexiou et al., 2019).

children.name: Challenges in participation
children.content:
Creating the conditions for meaningful participation requires careful
attention to the sensitivities that shape discussions about urinary
tract infections. The intimate nature of the symptoms and the social
taboos associated with bodily functions and sexual health often make
people hesitant to share their experiences. Feelings of stigma, fear of
judgment, and limited confidence in describing bodily sensations can
silence important aspects of their condition, especially for those who
live with recurrent infections. These constraints highlight the need for
alternative ways of engaging with experience. Visual and material modes
of expression, such as drawing, mapping, or working with physical
objects, offer accessible and less exposing pathways for communication
(Prochner, 2022). These practices redirect attention toward external
artefacts that participants can shape in ways that match their comfort
and abilities, creating an environment that supports trust and openness.
Following these considerations, this research adopts participatory
methods that emphasise confidentiality, empathetic engagement, and
participant control. Physical artefacts and materials act as mediators
through which personal experiences can be expressed safely, enabling
them to move from private and often stigmatized realities to shared
evidence that can inform both design enquiry and clinical understanding.

children.name: Introduction
children.content:
Participatory activities are most effective when they build on the
assets and forms of knowledge that participants already hold.
Encouraging collaboration between patients and clinicians to identify
what information matters and how to interpret it can lead to more
grounded and inclusive outcomes (Choe, 2015). Meaningful involvement
begins when individuals can express their own experiences and needs,
contributing to healthcare solutions that respond to lived realities
rather than assumptions. To support this, Fiske et al. (2019) emphasise
the importance of ethical frameworks that define goals and procedures
clearly, ensuring that participants contribute to shaping research
questions and design decisions. These frameworks recognise that all
contributors deserve transparency, acknowledged relevance, and fair
distribution of benefits, which in turn requires trust in institutions
and in the relationships formed during the process. Building such trust
involves inviting participants to co create the principles that will
guide collaboration. Shared goals established from the outset help
create a sense of ownership, particularly when personal data and
narratives are involved.

Building this sense of ownership requires involving participants in
co-creating the principles guiding collaborative work. Establishing
shared goals and conditions at the outset fosters trust and engagement,
particularly when projects involve personal data and narratives
(Shadlyn, 2022). Structured methods can also help initiate dialogue
among participants who may not know each other. Techniques such as
vignettes with prompting questions (Shadlyn et al., 2022),
peer-interview guides to support memory, context mapping, and event
sequencing (Groeneveld, 2018), or short ethnographic stories to trigger
collaborative reflection (Slegers et al., 2013) have proven effective.
These approaches align with narrative enquiry, which organises shared
stories to reveal clusters of meaning and validate findings (Groeneveld,
2018).

Further recommendations aim to strengthen participation by reducing
jargon, clarifying expected outcomes, sharing results with contributors
before public release, and acknowledging the limits of protocols and
tools (Price et al., 2017). Access to data can support action but does
not guarantee democratisation, especially when projects rely on
contributions from highly educated groups (Fiske et al., 2019).
Participation that invites people to share experiences yet limits their
influence to consultation can lead to frustration and reinforce existing
hierarchies. As De Moya (2020) notes, such conditions risk transforming
participation into symbolic compliance rather than fostering meaningful
collaboration.

children.name: Participatory Action Research (PAR)
children.content:
Participatory Action Research (PAR) offers a way to counter these issues
by integrating action and research within a single process, which
considers participants and researchers together in identifying problems,
experiment and design solutions. Knowledge is simultaneously produced
and employed (Tygel & Kirsch, 2016). PAR considers researchers and
citizens working together without imbalances, as citizens are not
considered the research’s objects (Price et al., 2017).

Researchers are facilitators collaborating to improve methodology,
create knowledge, overtake barriers, and open minds and possibilities.
They become co-investigators, together with individuals of oppressed or
marginalised groups, helping in examining specific conditions and
problems (Louie, 2022). Furthermore, the role of researchers in
promoting data literacy should not only be relegated to developing
methods and capacities to configure data structures but they should also
be focused on experimentation in participation and involvement
activities (Lury & Wakeford, 2014).

Meaningful collaboration grows from practices that are ethically
grounded and shaped with participants, acknowledging their experiences
as central to the enquiry. This orientation is central to this research,
which seeks to generate knowledge about UTIs while also advancing
participatory design methodology.

children.name: 2.4.3 Patient definition and role
children.content:
Healthcare contexts often acknowledge individuals as experts only in
relation to the diseases they experience, yet the broader skills and
knowledge they hold frequently remain unrecognised. Professional
competencies, lived experience, and practical problem solving abilities
can play an important role in identifying needs and informing more
appropriate responses to health challenges (Gilbert, 2020).
Constructivist pedagogical approaches strengthen this view by treating
people as active contributors in the creation of understanding that
helps improve their circumstances (D’Ignazio and Bhargava, 2018). In
line with this perspective, the research refers to women with experience
of UTIs or other medical conditions as people experienced with the
disease. This terminology conveys the diversity of capacities they
bring, rather than framing them solely as patients defined by a
diagnosis. Clinical settings continue to rely on the term patient
because of its convenience, although it does not capture the full extent
of lived expertise that shapes how individuals interpret and manage
their condition.

Attention to this broader understanding of expertise also highlights the
importance of the social environments that surround individuals.
Families, caregiver organisations, and advocacy groups often contribute
knowledge, coordination, and emotional support that exceed what any one
person can provide. These collectives act as significant agents in
healthcare, influencing biopolitical and ethical decisions through
shared commitments and organised action (Beier et al., 2016). Collective
agency becomes especially relevant in cases of under recognised
illnesses, where joint efforts can raise awareness, shape research
agendas, and provide mutual support for those affected. Recognising both
personal and collective forms of expertise underpins the participatory
orientation of this research, which seeks to create conditions where
these contributions actively inform knowledge production and support
more inclusive healthcare practices.

children.name: 2.4.4 Participation within the process of data physicalization
Introduction
children.content:
Considering the central role of data physicalization in this research,
this section focuses on participation and participatory practices in the
physical shaping of data and information. In this context, the emphasis
on participation reflects a broader shift in recent work on data
physicalization, which has moved from viewing artefacts as static
outputs to understanding them as part of dynamic processes of creation
and engagement. This perspective acknowledges that meaning is not
contained in the final object alone but develops through the
interactions, decisions, and reflections that occur during its making
and use. Participation provides the setting for this process-oriented
approach. When individuals actively contribute to shaping the data that
represents their experiences, physicalization becomes a medium for
dialogue, exploration, and collective interpretation.

This approach positions data physicalization as an active and situated
practice shaped through continuous participant involvement. Engagement
begins during data collection, where participants decide what is
meaningful to capture and how their experiences should be represented.
Collaborative creation of artefacts then supports the translation of
these insights into tangible form, integrating personal perspectives and
values into the material expression of data. The process continues in
participatory presentation settings, where the artefacts are discussed,
handled, or reconfigured. These encounters turn the physical objects
into activators of conversation, enabling shared interpretation and
further reflection.

By examining projects that embrace this participatory approach, this
section explores how data physicalization can support collective sense
making, enabling diverse voices to contribute to the construction of
knowledge.

children.name: Participatory Data Physicalization
children.content:
Participatory Data Physicalization (PDP) is described in the literature
as a dynamic, socially embedded process where data representation
becomes a shared, physical act of meaning-making. Rather than
positioning audiences as passive recipients, PDP involves them as active
contributors. Participants bring their own data and interpretations,
influencing both the form and content of the physicalization. This
creates a recursive process in which individuals act as subjects,
authors, and audience of the data they engage with (Moretti & Mattozzi,
2017).

PDP is framed not only as a method of representing information but as a
means of fostering engagement, dialogue, and reflection. By turning
abstract or digital information into tangible forms, PDP enables
collective awareness around issues that are often difficult to
communicate otherwise. The material nature of the medium supports
real-time, situated interactions, allowing local publics or co-located
groups to collaboratively construct meaning through guided and
open-ended participation (Sauvé, 2023; Panagiotidou & Vande Moere,
2022).

Whether structured through defined rules or facilitated more fluently,
PDP positions data as a mediator of social interaction and shared
understanding. As Cazacu et al. (2025) note, PDP functions as a
participatory approach where stakeholders co-create physical artefacts
that embody negotiated meanings. Through this process, participants
externalise perspectives, negotiate interpretations, and contribute to
the creation of collective knowledge. PDP thus emerges as a
participatory and interpretive practice grounded in embodiment,
collaboration, and the empowerment of those whose experiences shape the
data.

Participation in data physicalization can occur at multiple moments
along the process. Early stages of data collection often introduce the
first opportunities for involvement, as participants decide what should
be captured and how these choices connect to their lived experience.
Later phases of discussion provide another arena for engagement, where
groups collaboratively encode, interpret, and make sense of the
resulting artefacts. The following sections examine these stages in
detail, tracing how participation develops and becomes embedded within
physicalization practices.

children.name: Participation for data collection
children.content:
Participation in data collection can turn the act of gathering
information into a shared, performative process. Using simple materials,
participants physically record their responses through gestures such as
placing a string or removing a token.

Each action contributes to a collective visual narrative shaped by the
traces of individual decisions. Projects like Data Strings (Domestic
Data Streamers, 2013) and Participatory Data Physicalization (Moretti &
Mattozzi, 2018) employ strings to represent participants’ positions
across categories, and producing tangible records of group input. Other
works, including The Happy Show (Sagmeister, 2015) and Physical Bar
Charts (Kimbell & Barry, 2017), rely on the removal of gumballs or
badges to create inverse bar charts that accumulate meaning over time.
Contributions may occur simultaneously or sequentially, with
participants adding to a shared outcome at different moments.

These projects prioritise engagement and collective expression, often
through open-ended gestures rather than the interpretation of specific
information. In such cases, the activity encourages self-expression and
social interaction rather than analytical decoding of data. Moving from
these open systems to contexts where materials carry predefined meaning
introduces a shift in the nature of participation. Rather than simply
adding to a collective display, participants begin to operate within an
established representational vocabulary. The task becomes one of
selecting, arranging, and combining physical components to communicate a
perspective, transforming participation into an active process of
interpretation and expression within specific parameters.

Data Badges (Panagiotidou et al., 2020) exemplifies this approach by
inviting participants to select tokens representing academic interests
to create personalised patches. These patches serve as visual summaries
of identity and as prompt for interaction, sparking conversations and
mutual recognition.

Edo (Sauvé et al., 2023) uses pre-assigned tokens to let participants
track the carbon emissions of their food choices, situating the activity
in a cafeteria to link data to everyday experience and stimulate
reflection. Similarly, Cairn (Gourlet & Dassé, 2017) engages FabLab
users in building totems from predefined tokens associated with their
activities. Individual contributions merge into a collective structure,
which then becomes a basis for shared reflection and discussion.

children.name: Participation for representation
children.content:
Participation can also unfold through collective processes of decoding
and engaging with representations once artefacts have been constructed.
Facilitators create physical representations using participants’ data,
and engagement emerges as people gather around these objects to examine,
interpret, and discuss what they reveal. This mode of interaction,
described as “participatory data translation” (Nissen and Bowers, 2015),
demonstrates how physical artefacts become focal points for shared
reflection and dialogue. Contemporary perspectives on data
physicalization recognise that meaning does not reside solely in
finished objects but arises through the interactions, gestures, and
conversations that accompany their use. Encoding therefore shifts from a
technical act defined by designers to a collaborative and embodied
activity in which meaning is co-constructed through material engagement
and social participation.

children.name: Participation for interpretation
children.content:
Participation for interpretation builds on approaches that balance
predefined structure with opportunities for participant agency. One
strategy combines fixed encoding rules with flexible elements that
invite adaptation. Co-Gnito (Panagiotidou et al., 2022) exemplifies this
model by guiding participants through game-like activities to co-create
an urban mental map. Certain encodings remain stable, while others can
be personalised, enabling individuals to articulate symbolic choices and
contribute as co-designers of meaning rather than as data providers.

Interpretation can also emerge through the use of open-ended materials
that prompt reflection and reconfiguration. In Mental Landscapes
(Lockton et al., 2020), modular laser-cut cards representing features
such as hills or bridges encourage participants to “think with things.”
Through annotating, rearranging, and combining these elements,
participants externalise internal states, express relationships, and
explore personal and shared experiences. The adaptability of the
materials turns them into mediators of knowledge construction,
supporting tactile engagement and creating common ground for negotiation
and imagination. The resulting configurations remain temporary, with
meaning developing through continuous material and social interaction.

Healthcare contexts offer further examples of participatory
interpretation grounded in slow, reflective engagement. Freeman et al.
(2023) frames data physicalization as a means for slow, embodied
engagement. Using duoethnography, a dialogical research method in which
two or more researchers critically juxtapose their perspectives through
structured dialogue, they pair reflective conversation with the creation
of physical data artefacts. This combination emphasises mutual
self-examination and situates data as a driver for dialogue rather than
a static endpoint. Their co-design work with older adults exemplifies
this approach, supporting calm, reflective interactions that contrast
with the speed and abstraction of typical healthcare data processes.
Acting as design probes and boundary objects, these physicalizations
reveal tensions between clinical efficiency and the nuanced, personal
meanings embedded in health data, underscoring the potential of
participatory interpretation to create more inclusive, contextually rich
understandings.

children.name: 2.5.1 Lack of structure in collecting process-based data physicalizations
children.content:
Participation in data physicalization often produces meaning through
negotiation, with materials acting as mediators that help participants
share perspectives and build mutual understanding. Many physicalizations
are intentionally designed to allow multiple interpretations, which
encourages rich exchanges but also leads to discussions that surface
informally during group interactions or final presentations. Such
openness can generate valuable insight, although the absence of a clear
structure often makes the resulting knowledge difficult to organise,
integrate, or communicate.

This research focuses on identifying and interpreting symptoms through a
process that requires individual experiences to be transformed into
forms of collective understanding. Achieving this transition calls for a
structured approach that supports both the organisation of interpretive
activities and the capture of their outcomes. A clear structure is
supposed to enable participants in articulating their experiences in
comparable ways and provides a shared basis for turning personal
insights into knowledge.

children.name: 2.5.2 Contribution: Introducing the physical variables
children.content:
A structured approach to collective interpretation requires a shared
basis through which participants can express and relate their
experiences. In this research, that basis emerges in the moment when
symptoms are associated with physical variables. Physical variables
refer to attributes such as shape, texture, weight, or flexibility that
participants use to externalise sensations and articulate how their
bodies feel. Defining and mapping these variables together forms a
central phase of the work, shaping how participants conceptualise their
symptoms, how they express them materially, and how they recognise
connections with others’ experiences. The nature of these variables also
introduces an inherent structure for organising and interpreting data,
supporting meaning making both during the participatory process and in
subsequent analysis. Careful facilitation ensures that participants can
contribute with confidence and that their input is recognised.

Mapping symptoms to physical variables creates a generative space in
which individual insights are exchanged, refined, and woven into shared
understanding. Positioning this collective definition as a core moment
of participation establishes a method for producing knowledge that
remains grounded in lived experience while becoming collectively
interpretable. The following chapter expands on the concept of physical
variables and examines their role in the data physicalization process
developed in this study.

children.name: 2.5.3 Moving to the methodology definition
children.content:
This research approaches UTIs as both a clinical condition and a
gendered issue, exposing how the undervaluing of subjective experience
in biomedical practice disproportionately affects women. UTIs highlight
a wider structural problem in healthcare in which measurable signs are
privileged over lived, embodied experience, contributing to diagnostic
gaps, recurrent illness, and excessive reliance on antibiotics.
Addressing these challenges requires a broader understanding of what can
be considered data and a recognition of people as active contributors to
knowledge production.

Feminist perspectives reinforce this shift by emphasising embodied
knowledge as essential evidence and challenging assumptions of
neutrality and objectivity in medicine. Data physicalization and
autographic design provide conceptual and practical foundations for
making subjective experience visible and meaningful, demonstrating that
data gains significance through context, material engagement, and
interpretation. Through embodiment, experience becomes a vital source of
insight rather than something to be filtered out.

Building on this understanding, the research adopts participation as a
way to connect individual experiences with collective interpretation.
Central to this approach is the use of physical variables for mapping
symptoms during workshops. These variables allow participants to
externalise sensations, compare perspectives, and co-create
representations of illness, supporting the transformation of personal
interpretations into shared knowledge. Materials play a central role by
enhancing perception, encouraging expressive engagement, and
facilitating communication.

Within this methodological orientation, the next chapter introduces
data-probes as specific components designed to activate participatory
mapping. Together with physical variables, they form the foundation of
the methodological framework developed in this study. This framework
outlines how participation, material engagement, and co-creation are
implemented in workshops, showing how subjective symptoms can be
translated into tangible forms that support individual reflection and
open meaningful dialogue with clinicians.
